item.description:
We need all hands to help stop the spotted knapweed invasion and save native plants!

The work isn't hard. All ages welcome!

All we have to do is remove the flower stalks and place them in garbage bags. Repeated cutting of the flower stalks during the plant's flowering season will stop the spread and, over time, kill the plants.  We'll be traveling as a group to various locations in the Forest to hunt down this invader.  The plants are now in full flower and will continue to bloom through October, which means we'll be holding as many work parties as we can to get these weed under control.

If you have a GPS and can help us map infestation sites, please bring it. Mapping is crucial to monitoring the spread of the weeds and assessing the effectiveness of the management program. 

If you are out in the woods and see spotted knapweed, you can report new infestation on line at  http://fmssf.salicicola.com/mobile/invasive/entry/, for entering from a mobile device

or at  http://fmssf.salicicola.com/invasive/entry/ for entry from a stationary computer. 

The map for tracking spotted knapweed can be found at http://fmssf.salicicola.com/invasive. Once new locations are entered, the map will be updated automatically.

What to bring: clippers, choppers, or favorite plant cutting tool, gloves, hat, sunscreen, insect repellent and water. We'll plan to work for about two hours.

I'm bringing my dog Belle. She may have to stay in the car or on leash while we work on the roadways, but we'll be taking a 2-4 m. walk after the work party. Bring a lunch if you'd like to join us.

Thanks!

Sharl

 

 

 

The picture at left, from salicicola.com, shows spotted knapweed pushing aside little bluestem and golden asters . Please help!
item.how_to_find_us: Meet at the MSSF Headquarters Parking Lot

group.name: Friends of Myles Standish State Forest Meetup Group

item.name: Blast Spotted Knapweed
